articles.headline: Exxon Mobil Just Wants to Be Loved
articles.snippet: If Exxon Mobil doesn’t learn to talk more straightforwardly about its beliefs, it will never stop being the world’s whipping boy.
articles.abstract: If Exxon Mobil doesn’t learn to talk more straightforwardly about its beliefs, it will never stop being the world’s whipping boy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last week, Exxon Mobil announced that it had made an astonishing $39.5 billion in 2006. No company in history, not Microsoft, not Wal-Mart, has ever come close to making the kind of annual profit that this 134-year-old oil giant generated last year.

articles.headline: Vehicles Crossing the Pond
articles.snippet: Though they have operations in every corner of the globe, U.S. automakers are only now introducing cars with foreign pedigrees.
articles.abstract: Though they have operations in every corner of the globe, U.S. automakers are only now introducing cars with foreign pedigrees.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Feb. 9  American auto companies have long talked globally but acted locally.

articles.headline: U.N. Troops Fight Haiti Gangs One Street at a Time
articles.snippet: In a risky move that will determine the security of the country, U.N. forces are taking on powerful gangs.
articles.abstract: In a risky move that will determine the security of the country, U.N. forces are taking on powerful gangs.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 5 — For years, street gangs have run Haiti right alongside the politicians. With a disbanded army and a corrupted wreck of a police force, successive presidents have either used the gangs against political rivals or just bought them off.

articles.headline: Forgive Me, Viewer, for I Have Confessed in a Banner Ad
articles.snippet: An advertising company is playing live video from a bar in online advertisements.
articles.abstract: An advertising company is playing live video from a bar in online advertisements.
articles.lead_paragraph: Courtney Stecker is obsessed with the idea of surviving a car crash over a bridge, he confided to the camera. And every time he drives over a bridge, he said, he shuts everyone else out and imagines his car sailing over the rail.

articles.headline: U.S. Inquiry on Bonds at Big Bank
articles.snippet: Bank of America said it was cooperating with a Justice Department investigation into bidding practices in the municipal bond business in exchange for leniency.
articles.abstract: Bank of America said it was cooperating with a Justice Department investigation into bidding practices in the municipal bond business in exchange for leniency.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America said yesterday that it was cooperating with a Justice Department investigation into bidding practices in the municipal bond business in exchange for leniency.

articles.headline: Figuring Out Gift Giving in the Age of $2,000-a-Pound Chocolate
articles.snippet: Chocolates that cost $2,000 a pound make no sense to economists, but the high-end retail sector is red-hot.
articles.abstract: Chocolates that cost $2,000 a pound make no sense to economists, but the high-end retail sector is red-hot.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you are still seeking the perfect gift for Valentine’s Day, have you considered a box of Noka chocolates?

articles.headline: A Chance to Pick Hospice, and Still Hope to Live
articles.snippet: New hospice programs give patients medical comfort while allowing for sophisticated medical treatments.
articles.abstract: New hospice programs give patients medical comfort while allowing for sophisticated medical treatments.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American health care system has long given patients a terrible choice: people told that they have a terminal illness must forgo advanced medical treatment to qualify for hospice care. Cancer patients have to pass up chemotherapy, for example, or patients with kidney failure must abandon dialysis.

articles.headline: Deadliest Bomb in Iraq Is Made by Iran, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: The assertion of an Iranian role in supplying the device to Shiite militias reflects broad agreement among American intelligence agencies.
articles.abstract: The assertion of an Iranian role in supplying the device to Shiite militias reflects broad agreement among American intelligence agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 — The most lethal weapon directed against American troops in Iraq is an explosive-packed cylinder that United States intelligence asserts is being supplied by Iran.

articles.headline: India Finds Its Economy on the Verge of Overheating
articles.snippet: After three years of near double-digit growth, signs of a potentially dangerous inflationary spiral are emerging.
articles.abstract: After three years of near double-digit growth, signs of a potentially dangerous inflationary spiral are emerging.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India, Feb. 8 — With breakneck growth, an outsourcing industry that leads the world and hundreds of millions of consumers demanding more class and comfort, India has an economy many countries would envy.

articles.headline: Giuliani Shifts Abortion Speech Gently to Right
articles.snippet: Rudolph W. Giuliani has directed questions on abortion toward discussion about judges, saying he would appoint “strict constructionist” jurists.
articles.abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani has directed questions on abortion toward discussion about judges, saying he would appoint “strict constructionist” jurists.
articles.lead_paragraph: As he prepares for a possible run for president — a road that goes deep into the heart of conservative America — Rudolph W. Giuliani takes with him a belief in abortion rights that many think could derail his bid to capture the Republican nomination.

articles.headline: Portugal to Vote on Putting End to Abortion Ban
articles.snippet: A referendum on loosening restrictive abortion laws has pitted the Socialist government against Roman Catholics.
articles.abstract: A referendum on loosening restrictive abortion laws has pitted the Socialist government against Roman Catholics.
articles.lead_paragraph: LISBON, Feb. 10 — Last week, children from two Roman Catholic day-care centers in the port city of Setúbal were sent home with a most unusual note: a fictional letter from a fetus to the woman who conceived and aborted it.

articles.headline: Putin Says U.S. Is Undermining Global Stability
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia accused the United States of provoking a new nuclear arms race.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia accused the United States of provoking a new nuclear arms race.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNICH, Feb. 10 — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia accused the United States on Saturday of provoking a new nuclear arms race by developing ballistic missile defenses, undermining international institutions and making the Middle East more unstable through its clumsy handling of the Iraq war.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Mark Landler

articles.headline: In India, the Golden Age of Television Is Now
articles.snippet: The pace of change in India is supercharged because the country is catching up to, and in some cases leapfrogging, developments that took decades to play out elsewhere.
articles.abstract: The pace of change in India is supercharged because the country is catching up to, and in some cases leapfrogging, developments that took decades to play out elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India

articles.headline: It’s Alive! Meet One of Biotech’s Zombies
articles.snippet: In its 25 years in drug research, Xoma has burned through $700 million and never earned an operating profit nor brought a product to market.
articles.abstract: In its 25 years in drug research, Xoma has burned through $700 million and never earned an operating profit nor brought a product to market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Berkeley, Calif.

articles.headline: In Niger, Trees and Crops Turn Back the Desert
articles.snippet: Farmers’ simple methods have helped revive millions of newly tree-covered acres in a dust-choked region.
articles.abstract: Farmers’ simple methods have helped revive millions of newly tree-covered acres in a dust-choked region.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUIDAN BAKOYE, Niger — In this dust-choked region, long seen as an increasingly barren wasteland decaying into desert, millions of trees are flourishing, thanks in part to poor farmers whose simple methods cost little or nothing at all.

articles.headline: Congress Finds Ways to Avoid Lobbyist Limits
articles.snippet: Lawmakers continue to invite corporate lobbyists to help pay for fund-raisers that look a lot like the ones that Congress just barred lobbyists from sponsoring.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers continue to invite corporate lobbyists to help pay for fund-raisers that look a lot like the ones that Congress just barred lobbyists from sponsoring.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 — The 110th Congress opened with the passage of new rules intended to curb the influence of lobbyists by prohibiting them from treating lawmakers to meals, trips, stadium box seats or the discounted use of private jets.

articles.headline: Memo to Shareholders: Shut Up
articles.snippet: Shareholders’ demands to make directors more accountable are getting results.
articles.abstract: Shareholders’ demands to make directors more accountable are getting results.
articles.lead_paragraph: TO all those public company shareholders who are trying to make directors more accountable to owners and more watchful over executives: Cheer up. Your efforts seem to be gaining genuine traction.

articles.headline: Deciding Eligibility for Oscar
articles.snippet: There has been a rise in skirmishes over who has the right to walk up and accept an Academy Award as a named producer.
articles.abstract: There has been a rise in skirmishes over who has the right to walk up and accept an Academy Award as a named producer.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Hollywood, a town full of prerogatives, there remains one significant privilege: collecting an Oscar and attending the elite Governor’s Ball for the winners, guests and Tinseltown royalty. And as long as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has its way, it will remain a privilege.

articles.headline: For Clinton and Obama, Different Tests on Iraq
articles.snippet: Both campaigns during the weekend road tested their strategies for dealing with the war in the primaries and beyond.
articles.abstract: Both campaigns during the weekend road tested their strategies for dealing with the war in the primaries and beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: KEENE, N.H., Feb. 11 — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was challenged on Iraq from corner to corner of New Hampshire this weekend, while Senator Barack Obama drew cheers in Iowa for his opposition to the war.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Failed Bid Is Setback for Growth at Nasdaq
articles.snippet: Now that its second bid to acquire the London Stock Exchange has failed, Nasdaq will have to come up with a new international expansion strategy.
articles.abstract: Now that its second bid to acquire the London Stock Exchange has failed, Nasdaq will have to come up with a new international expansion strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Nasdaq Stock Market faces the task of rebuilding its foreign expansion strategy after the emphatic rejection this weekend of its second unwelcome bid to acquire the London Stock Exchange.

articles.headline: The No-Name Brand Behind the Latest Flat-Panel Price War
articles.snippet: In the battle for the market share in big-screen TVs, an upstart made a splash by selling its sets for almost half its regular price.
articles.abstract: In the battle for the market share in big-screen TVs, an upstart made a splash by selling its sets for almost half its regular price.
articles.lead_paragraph: If his Olevia line of televisions was ever going to get any attention from consumers, Vincent F. Sollitto Jr. would have to do something big, splashy and, in economic terms, just plain crazy.

articles.headline: Questions Grow About a Top CNBC Anchor
articles.snippet: CNBC’s ratings are growing, and so are questions about Maria Bartiromo, the network’s  most recognizable face.
articles.abstract: CNBC’s ratings are growing, and so are questions about Maria Bartiromo, the network’s  most recognizable face.
articles.lead_paragraph: In November 2005, Citigroup gathered top clients at a lush spa resort in Napa Valley for two days of wine tasting and a chance to road test some of the hottest luxury cars on the market.

articles.headline: White Knight Turns Pragmatist, and Newspapers Tremble Again
articles.snippet: Gary B. Pruitt, the head of the McClatchy Company, seems to have lost his place as the darling of the industry.
articles.abstract: Gary B. Pruitt, the head of the McClatchy Company, seems to have lost his place as the darling of the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than a year ago, Gary B. Pruitt, the head of the McClatchy Company, was hailed as the white knight of newspapers. While others saw the industry headed for the dinosaur graveyard, Mr. Pruitt rode in to buy the Knight Ridder papers, or some of them anyway.

articles.headline: U.S. Says Arms Link Iranians to Iraqi Shiites
articles.snippet: Senior U.S. military officials presented their first public evidence for the assertion that Iran is supplying Shiite extremists in Iraq with lethal weapons.
articles.abstract: Senior U.S. military officials presented their first public evidence for the assertion that Iran is supplying Shiite extremists in Iraq with lethal weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Feb. 11 — After weeks of internal debate, senior United States military officials on Sunday literally put on the table their first public evidence of the contentious assertion that Iran supplies Shiite extremist groups in Iraq with some of the most lethal weapons in the war. They said those weapons had been used to kill more than 170 Americans in the past three years.

articles.headline: Nuclear Talks on North Korea Hit Roadblock
articles.snippet: The negotiations appeared near collapse on Sunday over North Korea’s demands for huge shipments of fuel oil and electricity.
articles.abstract: The negotiations appeared near collapse on Sunday over North Korea’s demands for huge shipments of fuel oil and electricity.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, Feb. 11 — Negotiations on a step-by-step deal that the Bush administration hopes will lead North Korea to give up its nuclear weapons program appeared near collapse on Sunday over North Korea’s demands for huge shipments of fuel oil and electricity before agreeing to a schedule for turning over its nuclear weapons and fuel.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and David E. Sanger
